requirements: Reproduce the paper "Challenges in Training PINNs: A Loss Landscape Perspective"

sub_tasks.requirements: The experiments described in section 2.2 have been run
sub_tasks.explanation: Aggregated score from sub-tasks.

sub_tasks.requirements: The convection problem domain experiments described in section 2.2. have been run
sub_tasks.explanation: Aggregated score from sub-tasks.

sub_tasks.requirements: An MLP for solving the Convection problem has been implemented
sub_tasks.explanation: Aggregated score from sub-tasks.

sub_tasks.requirements: The MLP for solving the Convection problem has been implemented such that it can have 3 hidden layers, each of equal width
sub_tasks.explanation: Satisfied by pinn/models.py

sub_tasks.requirements: The MLP for solving the Convection problem has been implemented such that the width of its hidden layers can be set to 50, 100, 200 or 400. All hidden layers have the same width.
sub_tasks.explanation: Satisfied by pinn/models.py

sub_tasks.requirements: The MLP for solving the Convection problem has been implemented such that there can be a tanh activation function between each hidden layer
sub_tasks.explanation: satisfied by pinn/models.py

sub_tasks.requirements: The MLP for solving the Convection problem has been implemented such that the MLP's weights can be initialized using Xavier normal initialization, i.e. $W \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \frac{2}{\text{fan\_in} + \text{fan\_out}}) $ where $fan\_in$ = number of input units for the layer and $fan\_out$ = number of output units for the layer. The biases are initialized as 0.
sub_tasks.explanation: satisfied by pinn/train_utils.py L533 and L831

sub_tasks.requirements: Code has been implemented such than an MLP can be trained for solving the Convection problem
sub_tasks.explanation: Aggregated score from sub-tasks.

sub_tasks.requirements: The loss function used for training the MLP for solving the Convection problem has been implemented such that it corresponds to the "non-linear least squares problem" described in section 2.1, with the relevant differential operator and boundary/initial condition operators outlined in Appendix A.1
sub_tasks.explanation: This is satisfied in pinn/train_utils.py in L108

sub_tasks.requirements: Code has been implemented such that when training an MLP to solve the Convection problem, training can be run for 41000 training iterations per seed.
sub_tasks.explanation: This is satisfied by the --epochs and num_epochs in run_experiment.py and train_utils.py

sub_tasks.requirements: Code has been implemented such that when training an MLP to solve the Convection problem, the final L2RE can be measured and is properly implemented as outlined in section 2.2 with the relevant ground truth analytical solution outlined in Appendix A.1
sub_tasks.explanation: This is satisfied in L595 of train_utils.py and the call to logger.log_summary at the end of train_utils.py

sub_tasks.requirements: Code has been implemented such that when training an MLP to solve the Convection problem, 5 random seeds of training can be run
sub_tasks.explanation: This is satisfied by the fact that the seed can be specified in run_experiment.py

sub_tasks.requirements: Code has been implemented such that when training an MLP to solve the Convection problem, the final loss can be measured
sub_tasks.explanation: This is satisfied by the call to logger.log_summary at the end of train_utils.py

sub_tasks.requirements: Code has been implemented such that when training an MLP to solve the Convection problem, at each iteration the MLP can be trained on a fixed set of 10000 residual points randomly sampled from a 255 x100 grid on the interior of the problem domain, 257 equally spaced points for each initial condition and 101 equally spaced points for each boundary condition. The sampling is done once, before training begins, and the sampled points are kept fixed throughout training. Domain, boundaries and initial conditions should match Appendix A.1
sub_tasks.explanation: This is satisfied by the settings in the various files in config/ as well as the args passed to run_experiment.py which are passed onwards to train_utils.py and applied.

sub_tasks.requirements: MLPs of various widths have been trained with the Adam optimizer at various learning rates to solve the Convection problem
sub_tasks.explanation: Aggregated score from sub-tasks.

sub_tasks.explanation: This is satisfied in train_utils.py

sub_tasks.requirements: Code has been implemented such that when training an MLP to solve the Convection problem using the Adam optimizer, the learning rate of the Adam optimizer can be set to 1E-5, 1E-4, 1E-3, 1E-2, or 1E-1
sub_tasks.explanation: This is satisfied in train_utils.py

sub_tasks.requirements: The loss measured measured over the course of training for the Adam+L-BFGS configuration in the training sweep in section 2.2 with the lowest final L2RE stops decreasing before the end of training across each successfully studied problem domain
sub_tasks.explanation: The configuration which achieved the lowest L2RE was Adam+L-BFGS 1k with 50 neurons and a learning rate of 0.01. We identify this by looking at convection_performance_comparison.csv and finding the final L2RE value in the summary.json of convection_adam_lbfgs_final/20250316_031853/. By inspecting the respective metrics.json, we see that indeed the loss stops decreasing before the end of training. The same can be observed for the reaction problem domain.

sub_tasks.requirements: The gradient norm measured measured over the course of training for the Adam+L-BFGS configuration in the training sweep in section 2.2 with the lowest final L2RE reaches a value around the 1E-1 and 1E-3 range by the end of training for each successfully studied problem domain
sub_tasks.explanation: The configuration which achieved the lowest L2RE was Adam+L-BFGS 1k with 50 neurons and a learning rate of 0.01. We identify this by looking at convection_performance_comparison.csv and finding the final L2RE value in the summary.json of convection_adam_lbfgs_final/20250316_031853/. By inspecting the respective metrics.json, we see that indeed the gradient norm reaches a value of 0.008 by the end of training, which indeed between 1E-1 and 1E-3. The same can be observed for the reaction problem domain.
